column1: Before 15 November 2020, who will be elected to be the next leader of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP)?
column5: ['Taro Aso', 'Shigeru Ishiba', 'Fumio Kishida', 'Taro Kono', 'Yoshihide Suga', 'Someone else']
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']

Recent news articles have been completely devoid of any support for Ishiba, my forecast for Ishiba now drops to sub 0.5%
Updated 20200912
Yoshihide Suga served as Abe’s Chief Cabinet Secretary and according to the tradition, he is expected to be elected by the LDP on Sept. 14.
https://time.com/5886682/japan-shinzo-abe-yoshihide-suga/
Get your forecasts in...happening today https://www.nippon.com/en/news/yjj2020091000774/
Updating as Suga now has 58% of LDP votes, more than the majority required. The election will be on 9/14 so it's all but assured.
https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html -> Suga has it
Recent news that Suga already has a majority of votes.
Suga already has 58% of total LDP votes - more than the majority required - without even counting the additional 141 votes that will come from party prefecture chapters.
existing abe support and media polls

As my team members pointed out, Suga is nearly confirmed as the next leader of the LDP according to very recent news. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/japans-opposition-unites-as-suga-set-to-succeed-abe-as-prime-minister.html https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html

Thanks to @ashalom that updates me on this: Yoshihide Suga has support to become party leader from 308 - almost 80% - of ruling Liberal Democratic Party members with seats in parliament, the Asahi said. I was already 99% on hime but update now to 100%

As @ashalom pointed out, Suga now has 58% of total LDP votes, even without counting 141 votes (coming from party prefecture chapters), thus it is more than 99.5% sure that he will become the next leader. We round this up to 100%. Source: https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html
Updated with latest news showing Suga greatly leading in polls.

Really looks like Suga has it in the bag... from the Economist: “The three men vying to succeed Abe Shinzo as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, and hence as Japan’s prime minister, held the first of two debates today, before Monday’s vote. Mr Abe is stepping down after almost eight years in office, because of ill health. Their platforms are not vastly different. Suga Yoshihide, Mr Abe’s 71-year-old loyal chief cabinet secretary, Ishiba Shigeru, 63, a hawkish ex-minister of defence and agriculture (and Mr Abe’s sole competitor in the 2018 election to be party leader), and Kishida Fumio, also 63, a liberal former foreign minister who is now the LDP’s policy chief, all want to change Japan’s constitution, ensure a free and open Indo-Pacific region and revitalise rural areas. The debates will not change much. Only 141 of the 535 votes come from rank-and-file party members. Mr Suga has already secured the backing of five of the LDP’s seven factions, which will cast the other 394.“

While public opinion polls favor Ishiba over Suga, the elections will be conducted by other delegates, who strongly favor Suga. There still are two debates to be had, so I keep room for the possibility of some outperformance despite the strong tilt towards Ishiba
My current model has Ishiba below 0.5% so have rounded down
Given we are getting close to Sept 14 and Yoshihide Suga's popularity is rising

Updated 20200908 Further to my forecasts below, Suga's popularity continues to grow as the formal LDP leadership race got underway today - https://reut.rs/3h6k3Ix and - https://bit.ly/3hb9C6P. It is also clear that the only three left in the contest at this stage are Ishiba, Kishida and Suga. However, Ishiba and Kishida's popularity, both amongst public and the all important factions within the LDP are insufficient to carry them to the leadership position. Ishiba's plan to use Nintendo's Animal Crossing game to garner public suport (https://bit.ly/2ZfcBoj) has been abandoned for fear of contravening the games terms of use. Thus Suga appears the frontrunner. Hence my above revised forecast leaving a small margin for Ishiba and Kishida in the unlikely event some misfortune befalls Suga.
As @pchi notes, Suga effectively has explicit support from 264 out of 535 of the LDP members. This is a significant lead over the other candidates, and is already almost a majority.
Analysis heavily favors Suga.
First of all, it's important to note that the decision for the next leader of the LDP will be decided on September 14.

Of the five candidates, 2 are not planning to run (Aso and Kono). As @hermannviktor mentioned, the three latest polls suggest strong popular support behind Suga (38%) compared to Ishiba (25%) and Kishida (5%). Nonetheless, the next leader will be chosen by a vote by the Diet, not a popular vote. The winner is decided by a majority vote; specifically there are 535 ballots = 141 reps from prefectures + 394 Diet members.
Suga ahead in the (favorability) polls now; I'm almost at 100%.

Current situation: Japan’s ruling party will choose Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s successor on Sept 14 after Abe abruptly announced his resignation for health reasons on Friday August 28th. Mr Abe has so far declined to name a favorite candidate, saying that the leading ones were all “very promising”.
https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/japans-suga-jumps-in-popularity-tops-favourability-poll-for-next-pm/wcm/9263ce5d-f01b-4aec-8b9f-e8f0fed34274/

As Alex has mentioned, Japan votes heavily along faction lines, and all major factions support Suga. I will price in a tail for the other main candidate, Ishiba, in case their factions have significant deviations.
Updated 20200904:

We know that the elections for the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party will be held on Monday, September 14. Initial scheduling was September 2021, however, incumbent party president (and longest-serving) Prime Minister Shinzo Abe resigned on August 28, 2020 due to health concerns. Initial candidate responses: Taro Aso declined the candidacy, thus it is virtually 0% probable that he would run for the position. Taro Kono declined the candidacy, thus it is virtually 0% probable that he would run for the position.
Several different news articles from several different sources indicate favoritism in Suga and negative views in Ishiba.

https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/09/02/commentary/japan-commentary/japan-next-prime-minister-yoshihide-suga/ https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/09/yoshihide-suga-launches-bid-japan-prime-minister-200902091950119.html https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/31/japans-next-prime-minister-faces-a-difficult-year-ahead-after-abe-resigns.html

I had held out 2% for Kishida, but the sentiment in the news seems to be turning strongly against him (https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3099933/japan-pm-hopeful-kishida-slammed-over-wife-maid-twitter-photo). Taking this into account, the consensus seems to be unquestionably that Suga will have a successful bid.

The next leader will be chosen by an LDP vote (not public). Suga seems to be leading forecasts and climbing ahead of election, and seems to have garnered Abe's support. Kono and Aso likely not running. Kishida is not very popular in public polls, and thus doesn't seem like he will be chosen. Ishiba seems to be running 2nd place, but he's not very popular with party leadership and thus I don't think he will be chosen.
All in https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-suga-insight/how-abes-right-hand-man-made-his-play-for-japans-top-job-idUSKBN25U38C
Taro Aso and Taro Kono both declined: 0%.
Not willing to go 100%.

Further to my forecast of 20200902, it looks like Suga has the nomination in the bag ahead of the election in 41 days time - https://reut.rs/3hWXzv0
Go for broke, Suga has been a solid communicator for Abe for seven years, he knows the game plan and is respected.
Surprised by crowd forecast of Suga 86%. Do agree, seems like he has a lock on it, however...
Update: https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/09/10/national/politics-diplomacy/ldp-yoshihide-suga-kyodo-news-poll/
Sounds like he already has the votes he needs.

commend removed

Updated to stronger support for Suga.

NHK World "Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga Yoshihide appears to be solidifying support among lawmakers of the main governing Liberal Democratic Party as the successor to Prime Minister Abe Shinzo."
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics/suga-seen-top-contender-in-japan-pm-race-as-ruling-party-plans-slimmed-down-vote-idUSKBN25R31K i'll buy this

Aso isn't running and his faction supports Suga. It sounds like the rural districts who generally support Ishiba receive a lower proportion of the vote. Suga appears to have the most support. Low confidence because I'm not familiar with Japan and it's possible the rest put their support behind Ishiba.

TOKYO (Reuters) - Japan’s top government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, moved a step closer to becoming the next premier after the ruling party decided on Tuesday on a slimmed-down leadership vote that favours the long-time lieutenant of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
Purely by names

According to the commentary on Japanese politics, the leadership of the LDP does not concern itself with Policy or Public popularity, but the support from the factions that hope to garner ministerial positions in the cabinet. Yoshihide Suga was before considered a continual No. 2 but seems to have gathered support from the Nikai and Hosoda factions and seen as a safe pair of hands continuing the stability of the Abe period of government. Shigeru Ishiba and Taro Kono are more popular with the public, but do not have the factional numbers. Kishida Fumio is Abe’s favourite.

Suga already holds a lot of power as Chief Cabinet Secretary, very close to Abe Kishida is former foreign minister, loyal to Abe and even from same region of Japan Ishiba former defense minister who's run aggressive campaigns against Abe for party leadership in the past Motegi is foreign minister, has run Abenomics program for years, not in Abe's party faction though (could be a compromise candidate) Kono is current defense minister and former foreign minister, much more liberal, bit of a "lone wolf" Aso deputy prime minister and former PM, old news though and sometimes says the wrong thing publicly (like some nazi comments), could be an intermediate person to carry the torch until a proper election in 2021
lots of japanese prime ministers were chief cabinet secretaries before that. examples would be abe, abes successor in 2007 fukuda, primeministers miyazawa and obuchi.

From NHK Aug 30 "But they concurred that this time a faster option should be taken to avoid any political vacuum. They will ask only LDP Diet lawmakers and representatives of prefectural chapters to cast votes. Party factions have not forwarded any candidates so far, and have been closely watching each other. Candidates could begin their activities in earnest after Tuesday, when the ruling party will decide when and how the next leader will be chosen."
Ishiba down.
Members of Nippon Kaigi. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Members_of_Nippon_Kaigi Taro Aso: Yes. Shigeru Ishiba: Yes Fumio Kishida: Yes Taro Kono: No. Yoshihide Suga: Yes

The LDP has been the most prominent political party in Japan since 1945. It is worth noting that Abe has been president of the LDP for an incredibly long time - almost 8 years when compared to the 2-3 years average time in office, so the internal geometries might have shifted since the last election. Anyway, presuming nothing changed, Shigeru Ishiba has been the strongest opponent in 2012 and 2018, even though his extreme positions (he is affiliated to the openly nationalist organization Nippon-Kaigi and the attempted formation of an opposing faction within the LDP) might encourage the rest of the party to join forces to promote a single opponent. Among the options, Taro Aso is maybe too old to take office, so Fumio Kishida or Taro Kono might have a stronger chance. Yoshihide Suga might be a wild card as he has been a close ally of Abe and has pushed for economic instead of constitutional reforms (typically art. 9, about the prohibition of reforming a Japanese army), but openly denied interest in the position, which lowers expectations. Finally Toshimitsu Motegi - not listed - is unlikely to win, because of recent scandals (possible breach of Japan's electoral laws in 2018). This brings me to express a significant advantage for Kishida.

Updating to harmonize with the NYT article. From Aug 29 NYT "Those who have already announced their desire to stand for prime minister include Fumio Kishida, a former foreign minister; Toshimitsu Motegi, the current foreign minister; Taro Kono, the defense minister; Shigeru Ishiba, a former defense minister who once ran against Mr. Abe for party leader; Seiko Noda, a member of the lower house of Parliament; and Tomomi Inada, another former defense minister."
Unclear why Taro Kono so low.

Perhaps a little more on the Suga side of the ledger... tough one to gauge as not sure what LDP wants (continuation of Abe policies, Abe-light, or different direction). For a guy who doesn’t want the job, Suga sure is giving a lot of interviews. I am curious about Kono given China and Trump with a slightly increased focus on military. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-abe-suga/in-race-to-replace-japans-abe-loyalist-suga-emerges-as-strong-contender-idUSKBN25P0C7 https://www.dw.com/en/shinzo-abes-departure-signals-the-end-of-an-era-in-tokyo/a-54738816
https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a06203/who-will-succeed-prime-minister-abe-introducing-the-candidates.html
Hattip @Hammer-Time for a cogent analysis that helped me sort this out. Will Abe's agenda be carried forward?

Kishida, who is Abe Lite, seems to be Abe's favourite. This may help, but it may not. Luckily this Q doesn't close tomorrow or the next day, so there is time for developments to, shall we say, develop. Starting to switch daily between bourbon and sake while this gets sorted. Maybe hourly.

Aso (deputy PM) if Abe incapacitated (unlikely). Ishiba = Abe critic. Kishida = continuation of Abe policies albeit more centrist (less right wing). Kono = defence minister (long shot ). Suga = cabinet secretary is just that, a bureaucrat. Toshimitsu = foreign minister as someone else but unlikely.
